Award.AwardTitle: NSF/SBE-BSF: How Past Collective Trauma of Suffering and Perpetrating Intergroup Violence Can Facilitate or Prevent Intergroup Violence in the Present

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The most defining feature of conflict between groups is also the most challenging to address: the suffering and perpetration of violence. Intergroup violence inflicts collective trauma for both victims and perpetrators, albeit in different ways. A growing field of research identifies such past experiences of trauma as an obstacle to conflict resolution. The collective memory of past trauma that implicates another group can facilitate and escalate conflict with that group long after those events. Understanding such issues may help society develop more peaceful interactions between groups in conflict within a society as well as between nations. Investigators in the U.S. along with investigators in Israel test a comprehensive theoretical approach that links collective trauma and future intergroup violence. One prediction is that both victims and perpetuators can perceive their group's collective trauma in similar ways: as either a threat, creating demands which outstrip one's ability to handle it; or as a challenge, strongly demanding but which can be overcome and result in positive outcomes. Cardiovascular research suggests that challenge responses involve healthier physiological states and more adaptive behavior than do threat responses. In the case of collective trauma, the stress response may have tremendous societal impact as well--by causing defense motivations that result in conflict escalation for all involved. In their project the investigators test the hypothesis that the determining factor in perceiving trauma as threat versus challenge is in-group glorification, or people's deference to their own group and tendency to view it as superior to other groups. By testing these hypotheses, this research can generate knowledge that could improve societal outcomes related to large-scale conflict. In addition, the project may inform efforts to develop evidence-based interventions that deal with collective trauma and the violence that stems from it.

Eight studies address four primary objectives. One aim is to understand how collective trauma perceptions can differ in ways that escalate or deescalate conflict. Among perpetrators, those who glorify their group should see their group's collective trauma of perpetrating violence as a threat to the group's image, whereas those who do not glorify their group should see it as a challenge. Among victims, those who glorify their group should see their group's collective trauma of suffering violence as a threat to the group's existence, whereas others should see it as a challenge and potential for growth. The second aim is exploring how historical representations of trauma affect motivation and intention to act. Cognitive representations of past trauma in terms of threat should make people defensive and take measures that ultimately facilitate future violence. Representing past trauma in terms of challenge should reduce defensive behavior and ultimately prevent future violence. The third aim is testing whether individuals with different historical representations of trauma have cardiovascular responses that reflect threat versus challenge stress responses. The fourth aim is determining whether experimental manipulations can shift threat representations into becoming challenge representations. To test these aims, the investigators use multiple methods, including self-report measures and impedance cardiography. Research participants are from multiple countries that have experienced collective trauma.

The international component of this research was supported by co-funding from the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The defining feature of intergroup conflict is as obvious as it is difficult to understand in all its complexity: the perpetration and suffering of violence. Intergroup violence almost always inflicts collective trauma, for both victims and perpetrators, if in different ways. Most of the literature in the growing field of research on trauma has focused on its negative effects for both individuals and groups, identifying trauma as an obstacle to conflict resolution and as a factor that facilitates and escalates conflict. Drawing on this and other literatures, the current project developed a comprehensive theoretical understanding of the link between collective trauma and future intergroup violence. The project tested innovative hypotheses regarding: whether collective trauma has the potential to prevent future violence; whether it can do so among both victim and perpetrator groups; how these effects of trauma are transmitted via historical representations and resulting motivations and physiological responses; how interindividual differences in ingroup glorification affect people?s historical representations of trauma; and whether negative effects of collective trauma can be turned into positive ones.

In a nutshell, we have shown empirical support for the argument that people perceive their group?s collective trauma either as threat or challenge, depending on their level of ingroup glorification. Among victims, those who glorify their group see their group?s collective trauma of suffering violence as a threat to the group?s existence, whereas those who do not glorify their group see it as a challenge and potential for growth. Among perpetrators, those who glorify their group see their group?s collective trauma of perpetrating violence as a threat to the group?s image, whereas those who do not glorify their group see it as a challenge. Threat representations led to defense motivations that facilitate violence, whereas challenge representations led to non-defensive motivations that prevent violence. In showing these phenomena, we 1) developed a model explaining how and when collective trauma can escalate or deescalate conflict; 2) explored victims? and perpetrators? historical representations of trauma, and the resulting motivations and behavioral intentions; 3) tested whether historical representations of trauma are also represented at the level of cardiovascular responses of threat and challenge. Using a multimethod approach of self-report measures and impedance cardiography, multiple field experiments and two physiological lab studies tested our theory among Israeli Jews in the context of the Holocaust, and Americans in the context of the ?war on terror.? In doing so, the project yielded crucial insights in the literatures on collective trauma, intergroup violence and conflict, conflict reduction and reconciliation, ingroup identification, and threat-challenge. Most of all, it helped transform our understanding of the link between collective trauma and future intergroup violence.

This project has therefore generated evidence-based knowledge on the link between (historical representations of) collective trauma and (de-)escalation of large-scale conflict and violence. It both advanced theory and created empirical knowledge on these phenomena relevant to psychology and other disciplines such as political science, conflict and security studies, sociology, and public health, among others. Thus, we also disseminated our findings in interdisciplinary journals read by audiences within and outside of psychology; altogether, the project is on track to lead to 5 publications of a new theoretical perspective and our various empirical findings; and several presentations at national and international conferences. The project has also contributed to the training and professional development of 2 postdocs, 3 graduate students, and more than 50 undergraduate research assistants, who have been involved in the various studies we conducted and published. Moreover, this project contributed to the transformation of the long-standing divide between basic (process oriented) and applied (problem-oriented) research by testing hypotheses of theoretical and scholarly interest at the center of important large-scale social problems. As such, this project contributes to the minimization of intergroup violence and maximizing intergroup reconciliation and peace.
